title: Hawkers in Gulistan, Motijheel question DSCC cases over extortion
text:
Hawkers in Gulistan, Motijheel question DSCC cases over extortion Obaidur Masum, bdnews24.com Previous Next Hawkers have raised questions over the Dhaka South City Corporation (DSCC) cases against 72 for ‘extortion’ after setting up illegal shops for hawkers on footpaths and streets in Gulistan and Motijheel areas 
They say the case is based on ‘information provided by Hawkers’ Rehabilitation Committee member and Bangladesh Hawkers League President MA Kashem, who himself is an ‘extortionist’. 
Many of those named in the case are not the people behind the extortion in the areas, the hawkers said. 
Hawkers Coordination Council Coordinator Abul Hossain, one of the accused in the case, told bdnews24.com that the naming of hawkers in the case is a result of a dispute in the platform of hawkers’ organisations – Bangladesh Hawkers’ Federation – following the recent eviction drive by DSCC. 
Federation President Kashem sided with Mayor Sayeed Khokon while some others opposed him, Abul Hossain said. 
“That’s why Kashem named the others along with the extortionists,” he added. 
DSCC conducted the eviction drive to free the footpaths and streets from illegal makeshift shops in mid-January. 
The evicted hawkers have been demonstrating demanding rehabilitation. They threatened DSCC Mayor Khokon that they would complain to Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. 
On Thursday, the DSCC filed the three cases of extortion against the background of the hawkers’ movement. The case dossiers show that the charges of extortion were brought against the 72 following investigative reports carried by national dailies and ‘information and evidence provided by Kashem’.
Hawkers’ Federation President Kashem has admitted to helping DSCC file the cases by providing the information. 
He told bdnews24.com on Friday night that five hawkers’ organisations had also provided information to DSCC. 
“The mayor sought lists of extortionists from the hawkers’ leaders during a meeting. Five registered organisations of the hawkers provided the lists. We actually provided the names published in newspapers,” he said. 
Kashem, however, denied that the names of hawkers’ leaders had been included in the lists. 
He said DSCC had named some hawkers’ leaders from the federation, who ‘joined the extortionists later’, after reviewing video footage of demonstration. 
Besides Abul Hossain, the hawkers’ leaders implicated in the cases include Hawkers’ Coordination Council leader Arif Chowdhury, Bangladesh Hawkers’ Union Advisers Sekendar Hayat, Abul Hashem Kabir, Muriskul Islam Shimul, Shafiqur Rahman Babul, Manjur Moin, Homeless Hawkers’ League General Secretary Khokon Majumder, and Homeless Hawkers’ Society leaders Khairul Bashar and Rafiqul Islam. 
Arif Chowdhury said Kashem could not evade responsibility as their leader. “If we are extortionists, he (Kashem) is also an extortionist, having been the federation chief,” he said. 
The hawkers alleged Kashem had embezzled several hundred thousand taka by providing ID cards to the hawkers at Tk 200 per head. 
DSCC official Muhammad Shamsul Alam, who initiated the cases with Motijheel, Paltan and Shahbagh Police Stations, did not reply to a question on whether the cases were based on information provided by Kashem. 
He also did not reply when asked if the city corporation had checked the names before initiating the cases. 
bdnews24.com spoke to the hawkers in Gulistan, Paltan, Baitul Mukarram, Zero Point, and Bangabandhu Avenue from the afternoon to night on Thursday. 
The hawkers identified many of the 72 accused as ‘extortionists’. 
They include Khalil, Burha Salam, Sarder Salam, Akter, Jahangi’, Kala Nabi, Abdur Rob,‘Hasan, Shaheed, Khorshed alias Borho Mia, Bimol Babu, Shawkat Habib, Bhola, and Kana Siraj. 
The hawkers could not identify many of the others. They said Lombu Shahjahan, Babul, Hindu Shaheen, and Ayub work as ‘lineman’, who collect edthe extortion from the hawkers on behalf of the main culprits.
Many others implicated in the cases were identified as hawkers like Manik’, a hairdresser with a makeshift arrangement on the footpath. 
One of the accused, Bangladesh Hawkers’ Union Adviser Manjur Moin, told bdnews24.com that the cases were aimed at stopping the movement against eviction. 
“But this wicked strategy will not be able to stop our movement,” he said. 
After the cases were initiated on Thursday, DSCC Mayor Sayeed Khokon said a quarter was trying to stop the eviction drive as they would lose the money they were getting through extortion. 
He also alleged political interference in the movement.
